Description: Drive has detected a high current in the output phase.
Recommended_Fixes: Sudden increase in load Check load. Short circuit in cables Check cables.

Description: DC−link voltage has exceeded the drive protection limits S1 = Hardware trip. Unit DC Voltage above 911VDC.
Recommended_Fixes: Power is sent back into the drive from load.

Description: Earth fault protection ensures that the sum of the phase currents is zero. S1 = Sum of output phase currents is not zero.
Possible_Causes: Insulation failure in cables.
Recommended_Fixes: Verify Verify the unit is grounded properly.

Description: Charge switch status is not correct when start command is given. S1 = Charge switch was open when the start command was given.
Possible_Causes: Charge switch was open when the start command was given.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check connection of the feedback from the charging relay. Reset the fault and restart.

Description: The F7 saturation fault is looking at the voltage from the collector to the emitter of the IGBT when the device is turned on. If the drive monitors greater than 7VDC when the device is on it sees this as too great of a voltage for the IGBT to be working properly. This fault is only active on the FR4−9 frame sizes. There are a few things that can cause this trip. IGBT did not turn on due to defective firing circuit or IGBT Monitoring circuitry is not monitoring the voltage correctly giving false trips A short on the output of the drive can make the IGBT the highest impedance load Poor grounding can cause noise that will trip the drive S1 = Hardware failure
Possible_Causes: Switch off power DO NOT RE−CONNECT POWER.
Recommended_Fixes: Contact Contact distributor.

Description: A system fault indicates several different fault situations in drive operation. It is important to get the subcode from the keypad on this fault. S1 = Reserved Disturbance. Rest the unit and try again. Driver board or IGBT is broken. S2 = Reserved S3 = Reserved S4 = Reserved S5 = Reserved S6 = Reserved S7 = Reserved S8 = No power to driver card S9 = Power unit communication (Tx) S10 = Power unit communication (Trip) S11 = Power unit comm. (Measurement) S12 = SystemBus synchronization has failed in DriveSynch Operation S30 = Safe disable inputs are in different state (OPT−AF) S31 = Thermistor short circuit detected (OPT−AF) S32 = OPT−AF board has been removed S33 = OPT−AF board EEPROM error
Recommended_Fixes: Call distributor

Description: DC−link voltage is below the fault voltage limit of the drive. S1 = DC−link too low during run. S2 = No data from power unit S3 = Undervoltage control supervision
Possible_Causes: Too low a supply voltage. Measure supply voltage.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check breakers and fuses. Drive internal fault.

Description: The IGBTs cannot sync to the generator’s sine waves. S1 = Phase supervision diode supply. S2 = Phase supervision active front end.
Possible_Causes: Input line phase is missing.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check supply voltage, fuses, and cable.

Description: Current measurement has detected that there is no current in one phase or one phase current is considerably different from other phases.
Recommended_Fixes: Check cables.

Description: Heatsink temperature is under 10°C.
The heat sink on the drive is measured at 89˚C or Higher.
Possible_Causes: Lower Load and Increase Airflow.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check heatsink for dust. Check the ambient temperature.

Possible_Causes: Parameter save fault. Faulty operation. Component failure.
Recommended_Fixes: Contact Contact distributor.

Description: Values displayed on counters are incorrect.
Possible_Causes: Values displayed on counters are incorrect. Have a critical attitude towards values shown on counters.
Recommended_Fixes: Contact Contact distributor.

Description: Error in loading application.
Possible_Causes: Start−up of the drive has been prevented. Run request is ON when a new application is loaded to the drive.
Recommended_Fixes: Reset Reset the fault and restart. Contact distributor.

Description: Error in loading application.
Possible_Causes: Start−up of the drive has been prevented. Run request is ON when a new application is loaded to the drive. Cancel prevention of start−up if this can be done safely.
Recommended_Fixes: Remove Remove Run Request. Contact distributor.

Description: The thermistor input of the option board has detected too high a motor temperature.
Possible_Causes: Load is over heated. Thermistor cable is broken.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check load. Contact distributor.

Description: IGBT Inverter Bridge over temperature protection has detected too high a short−term overload current. Treat as over current.
Recommended_Fixes: Sudden increase in load Check load. Short circuit in cables Check cables.
Cooling fan of the frequency converter does not start when ON command is given.

Description: Option board or power unit changed.
Possible_Causes: New device of same type and rating.
Recommended_Fixes: Reset Reset fault and start again.

Description: Option board added.
Possible_Causes: New device of same type and rating.
Recommended_Fixes: Reset Reset fault and start again.

Description: Option board removed.
Possible_Causes: New device of same type and rating.
Recommended_Fixes: Reset Reset fault and start again.

Description: Unknown option board or drive. S1 = Unknown Device. S2 = Power1 not same type as Power2.
Recommended_Fixes: Contact distributor.

Description: IGBT Inverter Bridge over temperature protection has detected too high a short−term overload current.
Recommended_Fixes: Sudden increase in load Check load. Short circuit in cables Check cables.

Description: Option board or power unit changed. New device of different type or different rating from the previous one
Recommended_Fixes: Reset  Reset Fault.

Description: Option board or power unit changed. New device of different type or different rating from the previous one
Recommended_Fixes: Reset  Reset Fault.

Description: Analog Signal reading issue.
Possible_Causes: 1.  Current at the analogue input is below 4mA.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check wiring.

Description: Digital input fault.
Recommended_Fixes: Ensure Ensure E−stop is out. Check E−stop wiring.

Description: Keypad is removed from drive.
Possible_Causes: The connection between the control keypad or NCDrive and the AC drive is broken.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check keypad connection/cable.

Description: The data connection between the HMI and drive is broken. The
Possible_Causes: Reset fault.
Recommended_Fixes: Verify Verify power is on to the drive and ethernet switch. Verify that the IP address in the drive has not been changed.

Description: Defective option board or slot. Drive has lost connection to a option card installed in control module.
Recommended_Fixes: Check options cards in drive are installed correctly. Do not remove card while drive is powered up.

Description: Digital input monitoring indicates that DC or AC input switch is open.
Recommended_Fixes: Verify wiring.

Description: Temperature protection function is used to measure temperature and give warning and/or fault when set limits are exceeded. AFEII application supports two temperature sensor boards simultaneously. A1 = Temperature limit has been exceeded. A2 = Sensor not wired or not working. A3 = Short circuit.
Possible_Causes: Temperature limit values set for the temperature board parameters have been exceeded.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check wiring.

Description: Protection for the liquid−cooled units. An external sensor is connected to the drive (DI: Cooling Monitor) to indicate if cooling liquid is circulating. If the drive is in Stop state only a warning is issued. In Run state a fault is issued, and the drive makes a coast stop.
Recommended_Fixes: Liquid cooled drive cooling circulation have been failed.

Description: Run Disable warning signal is issued when Run Enable signal has been removed from the IO.

A1: Code given by V002 and older versions. A2: MCB open, while command is to close. A3: MCB closed, while command is to open. A4: MCB opened externally while AFE unit was in run state. A5: MCB Trip state, Digital input from the MCB
Recommended_Fixes: MCB has opened while drive controls it to close. MCB is closed while drive controls it open. MCB is opening while AFE unit is in Run state.

Description: Temperature protection function is used to measure temperature and give warning and/or fault when set limits are exceeded. AFEII application supports two temperature sensor boards simultaneously. A1: Temperature limit has been exceeded. A2: Sensor not wired or not working. A3: Short circuit.
Possible_Causes: 1. Temperature limit values set for the temperature board parameters have been exceeded.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check Wiring.

Description: Klixon type temperature sensor has exceeded the triggering limit.
Recommended_Fixes: Check reason for temperature trip where Klixon sensor is located.

Description: Loss of communication to the OPTE9 card. Slot E is the 5th slot in the drive (Furthest to the right).
Recommended_Fixes: Reset fault. If the fault is persistent, try a new OPTE9 card. This must be configured based on each drive.

Description: Digital input connected to LCL indicates fan fault.
LCL Temperature has reached warning limit.
A license must be generated at Spoc for the dc−dc and grid inverter application to run. If the code is wrong the drive will show this fault when it tries to start.
Recommended_Fixes: The license code should be on a sticker behind the keypad of the drive. Enter it into the license code. Call Spoc.

Description: The drive has not reached DC voltage at set time to MCB. Drive pre−charge issue.
Recommended_Fixes: Charging circuit not operational. High load in DC link. Low voltage in supply for charging circuit.

Description: Digital input fault.
Recommended_Fixes: Remove the fault situation from the external device.

Description: Digital input fault.
Possible_Causes: Verify E−stop is pulled out.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check Wiring.

Description: Digital input fault.
Recommended_Fixes: Remove  Remove fault situation from external device.

Recommended_Fixes: Remove  Remove fault situation from external device.

Recommended_Fixes: Remove fault situation from external device.

Description: Supply voltage is not inside of set limits.
Possible_Causes: Verify breakers are closed.
Recommended_Fixes: Verify Verify fuses. Ensure generator voltage (480VAC).

Description: Digital input fault.
Possible_Causes: Verify E−stop is pulled out.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check Wiring.

Description: Line THD is too high.
Line HF Voltage is too high. DC−DC Drive Faults
Drive has detected a high current in the output phase.
Recommended_Fixes: Sudden increase in load Check load. Short circuit in cables Check cables.

Description: DC−link voltage has exceeded the drive protection limits S1 = Hardware trip. Unit DC Voltage above 911VDC.
Recommended_Fixes: Too short a deceleration time. High overvoltage spikes in supply. Power is sent back into the drive from load.

Description: The master drive sends pulses to all follower drives. If the pulses are missing a system bus communication fault is generated. The master drive also receives pulses back from the follower drives (max. four drives) and generates warnings if pulses are missing. SystemBus communication is broken between master and follower. Correcting measures: Check expander board parameters. Check optical fiber. Check option board jumpers.

Protection for the liquid−cooled units. An external sensor is connected to the drive (DI: Cooling Monitor) to indicate if cooling liquid is circulating. If the drive is in Stop state only a warning is issued. In Run state a fault is issued, and the drive makes a coast stop.
Recommended_Fixes: Liquid cooled drive cooling circulation have been failed.

Description: Actual current is not within current reference hysteresis. See parameter group G2.10.6 Reference Error.
Run Disable warning signal is issued when Run Enable signal has been removed from the IO.
A command has been given from a digital input or the fieldbus to make a quick stop.

Temperature protection function is used to measure temperature and give warning and/or fault when set limits are exceeded. AFEII application supports two temperature sensor boards simultaneously. A1: Temperature limit has been exceeded. A2: Sensor not wired or not working. A3: Short circuit.
Possible_Causes: Temperature limit values set for the temperature board parameters have been exceeded.

Description: A license must be generated at Spoc for the dc−dc and grid inverter application to run. If the code is wrong the drive will show this fault when it tries to start.
Recommended_Fixes: The license code should be on a sticker behind the keypad of the drive. Enter it into the license code. Call Spoc.

Description: When using the normal master follower function this fault code is given if one or more follower drives trip to fault. This fault is visible also when fault is in master drive. See also what other faults may be active in master drive.
Recommended_Fixes: Fault in follower drive or in Master drive.

Description: Interleaving modulation is not synchronized between the drives.
Recommended_Fixes: Different settings between the drives.

Description: The drive has not reached DC voltage at set time to MCB. Drive pre−charge issue.
Recommended_Fixes: Charging circuit not operational. High load in DC link. Low voltage in supply for charging circuit.

Description: Feedback signal deviates from calculated source voltage more than set limits.
Digital input fault.
Possible_Causes: Verify E−stop is pulled out.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check Wiring.

Description: Source voltage has exceeded source Min or Max voltage.
Possible_Causes: Verify Drive parameters are set correctly.
Recommended_Fixes: Verify Verify battery voltage is accurate.

Description: Freely selectable signal monitoring value has exceeded set limit levels. Grid Inverter Drive Faults
Drive has detected a high current in the output phase.
Recommended_Fixes: Sudden increase in load Check load. Short circuit in cables Check cables.

Recommended_Fixes: Sudden change in supply voltage or frequency. Unstable DC power source in uGrid mode. Power is sent back into the drive from load.

Possible_Causes: Input line phase is missing.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check supply voltage, fuses, and cable.

Description: Identification run has failed.

Protection for the liquid−cooled units. An external sensor is connected to the drive (DI: Cooling Monitor) to indicate if cooling liquid is circulating. If the drive is in Stop state only a warning is issued. In Run state a fault is issued, and the drive makes a coast stop.
Recommended_Fixes: 1.  Liquid cooled drive cooling circulation have been failed.

Description: Run Disable warning signal is issued when Run Enable signal has been removed from the IO.
A command has been given from a digital input or the fieldbus to make a quick stop.

Temperature protection function is used to measure temperature and give warning and/or fault when set limits are exceeded. AFEII application supports two temperature sensor boards simultaneously. A1: Temperature limit has been exceeded. A2: Sensor not wired or not working. A3: Short circuit.
Possible_Causes: Temperature limit values set for the temperature board parameters have been exceeded.

Description: Loss of communication to the OPTE9 card. Slot E is the 5th slot in the drive (Furthest to the right).
Recommended_Fixes: Reset fault. If the fault is persistent, try a new OPTE9 card. This must be configured based on each drive.

Description: This monitors Grid frequency and voltage for external grid synchronization function. Warning is given when request to synchronize is given and voltage and/or frequency is out of the warning limits defined in G2.9.6 and G2.9.7 voltage and frequency warning limits.
Possible_Causes: Restart the energy boss with no load. OPT−D7 measurements are not within limits.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check fuses to the d7 transformer.

Description: The OPT−D7 card is not recognized in the grid converter drive (The optd7 card goes in slot C on the control module).
Possible_Causes: Verify that the card is seated properly in the grid converter control module.
Recommended_Fixes: Verify Verify that the drive is showing the correct optd7 output voltage.

Description: Supply voltage is not inside of set hysteresis. Not to be confused with OPT−D7 protections.
LCL Temperature has reached warning limit.
A license must be generated at Spoc for the dc−dc and grid inverter application to run. If the code is wrong the drive will show this fault when it tries to start.
Recommended_Fixes: The license code should be on a sticker behind the keypad of the drive. Enter it into the license code. Call Spoc.

Description: Supply frequency is not inside of set hysteresis, set in G2.9.7. Not to be confused with OPT− D7 protections that will give F93 D7 Frequency.
Recommended_Fixes: Lower load on the system.

Description: The drive has not reached DC voltage at set time to MCB. Drive pre−charge issue.
Recommended_Fixes: Charging circuit not operational. High load in DC link. Low voltage in supply for charging circuit.

Description: Digital input fault.
Possible_Causes: Verify E−stop is pulled out.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check Wiring.

Description: In Master−Follower Mode Grid side drive has an active fault that is shown in master drive as a fault.

Drive has operated against current limit for more than short circuit time. By phase fault detection has seen low voltage for more than short circuit time. Warning comes immediately when current is at current limit, fault comes after the short circuit time
Recommended_Fixes: There is a short circuit in the grid.

Description: The feedback voltage from the output of the grid converter is not within the accepted range of output voltage. The acceptable range is 80% of the target output voltage. Normally this is set to 480V but if you move up the output voltage this increases. It must fall below the trip point for 3 seconds before it faults. ex. target voltage = 480Vac , Low trip point = 384Vac.
Possible_Causes: Lower/remove load and run the energy boss open.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check fuses going to the D7 transformer. Remove load and turn off the D7 protections. This will allow you to run the drive and see what the D7 voltage is reading. If the D7 voltage is reading low, start tracing the circuit from There should be 480V at the output 480Vac breaker. Verify that the d7 transformer is getting 480V into the transformer. The d7 transformer is a 1 to 60 ratio. You should have about 8Vac on the secondary side. If you do not then the transformer is bad. (Note there is no reference to ground on this, it is only phase to phase) Verify that the same 8Vac is going into the optd7 card on the grid converter control module.

Description: The feedback frequency from the output of the grid converter is not within the accepted range of output frequency. The acceptable range is 95% of the target output frequency. Normally this is set to 60Hz but if you move up the output frequency this changes . It must fall below the trip point for 3 seconds before it faults. ex. target voltage = 60Hz, Low trip point = 57Hz.
Possible_Causes: Lower/remove load and run the energy boss open.
Recommended_Fixes: Check Check fuses going to the D7 transformer. Remove load and turn off the D7 protections. This will allow you to run the drive and see what the D7 frequency is reading. If the D7 frequency is reading low, start tracing the circuit from There should be 480V at the output 480Vac breaker. Verify that the d7 transformer is getting 480V into the transformer. The d7 transformer is a 1 to 60 ratio. You should have about 8Vac on the secondary side. If you do not then the transformer is bad. (Note there is no reference to ground on this, it is only phase to phase) Verify that the same 8Vac is going into the optd7 card on the grid converter control module.

Description: Freely selectable signal monitoring value has exceeded set limit levels. Toshiba Battery System Battery Communication Issue Troubleshooting Steps Is the BMU communicating? No … Does the BMU have 12V on the input? Check 12V power supply and fusing. Is the ethernet cable landed on the BMU and switch? Is the ethernet switch powered up with 24V? Yes, the BMU is communicating. Is the BMU fault cycling on fault reset? (Fault clears briefly then comes back) No… To clear a fault the power must be cycled on the BMU. Verify that power is cycling into the BMU. Verify the relay controlling the power cycle of the BMU is cycling on fault reset. If not, then replace the relay. Yes, the fault is cycling. Is the CT communicating? No… Verify it is wired correctly. Verify it has 12V on pin 20 (+12VDC) to pin 22 (−12VDC). If not then verify the connector is plugged into the BMU. Verify CanH and CanL to the BMU (pin 25 and 26). Verify that wires 20,22,25, and 26 have continuity from the pin of the BMU connector to the end of the BMU connector wire. Replace CT cable. Replace CT. Replace BMU Cable. Replace BMU. Yes, the CT is communicating. Are the batteries communicating? No… Verify the BMU is not in the maintenance mode. Verify Pin 8 does not have continuity to ground. Verify wiring. Verify BMU has +12VDC on pin 1 to GND pin 7. Verify Pin 13 has 12VDC (power supply signal). Verify Pin 20 has 12V to CT. Verify Pin 22 has continuity to ground.
